Spatial Dynamics of a Nonlocal Dispersal Population Model in a Shifting Environment

Wan-Tong Li1, Jia-Bing Wang1,2,,  Xiao-Qiang Zhao2
1School of Mathematics and Statistics, Lanzhou University,
Lanzhou, Gansu 730000, People’s Republic of China
2Department of Mathematics and Statistics, Memorial University
of Newfoundland, St. John’s, NL A1C 5S7, Canada
Abstract

This paper is concerned with spatial spreading dynamics of a nonlocal dispersal population model in a shifting environment where the favorable region is shrinking. It is shown that the species will become extinct in the habitat once the speed of the shifting habitat edge c>c∗​(∞)𝑐superscript𝑐c>c^{*}(\infty), however if c<c∗​(∞)𝑐superscript𝑐c<c^{*}(\infty), the species will persist and spread along the shifting habitat at an asymptotic spreading speed c∗​(∞)superscript𝑐c^{*}(\infty), where c∗​(∞)superscript𝑐c^{*}(\infty) is determined by the nonlocal dispersal kernel, diffusion rate and the maximum linearized growth rate. Moreover, we demonstrate that for any given speed of the shifting habitat edge, this model admits a nondecreasing traveling wave with the wave speed at which the habitat is shifting, which indicates that the extinction wave phenomenon does happen in such a shifting environment.

Keywords: Spreading speed, extinction wave, nonlocal dispersal, shifting environment.

AMS Subject Classification (2010): 35K57, 35R20, 92D25

1 Introduction

In this paper, we are interested in the following nonlocal dispersal population model in a shifting environment:

∂u​(t,x)∂t=d​(J∗u−u)​(t,x)+u​(t,x)​(r​(x−c​t)−u​(t,x)),t>0,x∈ℝ,formulae-sequence𝑢𝑡𝑥𝑡𝑑∗𝐽𝑢𝑢𝑡𝑥𝑢𝑡𝑥𝑟𝑥𝑐𝑡𝑢𝑡𝑥formulae-sequence𝑡0𝑥ℝ\frac{\partial u(t,x)}{\partial t}=d\left(J\ast u-u\right)(t,x)+u(t,x)(r(x-ct)-u(t,x)),~{}t>0,x\in\mathbb{R}, (1.1)

where u​(t,x)𝑢𝑡𝑥u(t,x) stands for the population density of the species under consideration at time t𝑡t and location x𝑥x. Here the convolution kernel J∈C​(ℝ,ℝ+)𝐽𝐶ℝsuperscriptℝJ\in C(\mathbb{R},\mathbb{R}^{+}) is even and compactly supported with unit integral, and J​(x−y)𝐽𝑥𝑦J(x-y) denotes the probability distribution of the population jumping from location y𝑦y to location x𝑥x. Then ∫ℝJ​(x−y)​u​(t,y)​dysubscriptℝ𝐽𝑥𝑦𝑢𝑡𝑦differential-d𝑦\int_{\mathbb{R}}J(x-y)u(t,y){\rm d}y is the rate at which individuals are arriving to location x𝑥x from all other places, while ∫ℝJ​(y−x)​u​(t,x)​𝑑y=u​(t,x)subscriptℝ𝐽𝑦𝑥𝑢𝑡𝑥differential-d𝑦𝑢𝑡𝑥\int_{\mathbb{R}}J(y-x)u(t,x)dy=u(t,x) is the rate at which they are leaving location x𝑥x to all other sites. It follows that

𝒜​u​(t,x):=(J∗u−u)​(t,x)=∫ℝJ​(x−y)​u​(t,y)​dy−u​(t,x)assign𝒜𝑢𝑡𝑥∗𝐽𝑢𝑢𝑡𝑥subscriptℝ𝐽𝑥𝑦𝑢𝑡𝑦differential-d𝑦𝑢𝑡𝑥\mathcal{A}u(t,x):=(J\ast u-u)(t,x)=\int_{\mathbb{R}}J(x-y)u(t,y){\rm d}y-u(t,x)

can be viewed as a nonlocal dispersal operator modeling the free and large-range migration of the species (see [13, 22]) and d>0𝑑0d>0 is the dispersal rate. The reaction term describes the logistic type growth of the species which depends on the density u𝑢u and on the shifting habitat with a fixed speed c>0𝑐0c>0. Throughout this paper, we always assume that the resource function r​(ξ)𝑟𝜉r(\xi) is a continuous and nondecreasing function with r​(±∞)𝑟plus-or-minusr(\pm\infty) finite and r​(−∞)<0<r​(∞)𝑟0𝑟r(-\infty)<0<r(\infty). Thus, the shifting environment may be divided into the favourable region {x∈ℝ:r​(x−c​t)>0}conditional-set𝑥ℝ𝑟𝑥𝑐𝑡0\{x\in\mathbb{R}:r(x-ct)>0\} and the unfavourable region {x∈ℝ:r​(x−c​t)≤0}conditional-set𝑥ℝ𝑟𝑥𝑐𝑡0\{x\in\mathbb{R}:r(x-ct)\leq 0\}, both shifting with speed c>0𝑐0c>0. Specifically, we see that when time increases, the unfavourable region is expanding and the favourable region is shrinking. This kind of problem comes from considering the threats associated with global climate change and the worsening of the environment resulting from industrialization which lead to the shifting or translating of the habitat ranges, and recently has attracted much attention, see, e.g., [2, 10, 12, 14, 24, 15, 11, 16, 35, 23, 28]. Model (1.1) may also be derived from some specific epidemiological models by the arguments similar to those in Fang, Lou and Wu [8], where the authors deduced a classical reaction-diffusion Fisher-KPP equation in a wavelike environment from the consideration of pathogen spread.

It is well known that nonlocal dispersal problem (1.1) with space-time homogeneous growth rate r>0𝑟0r>0, i.e., ut=d​(J∗u−u)+u​(r−u)subscript𝑢𝑡𝑑∗𝐽𝑢𝑢𝑢𝑟𝑢u_{t}=d(J\ast u-u)+u(r-u), has been fully investigated for the spatial spreading dynamics. Here we refer to [5, 26, 34, 3] for the existence and uniqueness of monotone traveling wave solutions, and [27, 21] for the spreading speed, and [17] for the construction of new types of entire solutions. Roughly speaking, the slowest speed

c∗=minλ>0⁡d​(∫ℝJ​(y)​eλ​y​dy−1)+rλsuperscript𝑐subscript𝜆0𝑑subscriptℝ𝐽𝑦superscript𝑒𝜆𝑦differential-d𝑦1𝑟𝜆c^{*}=\min_{\lambda>0}\frac{d\left(\int_{\mathbb{R}}J(y)e^{\lambda y}{\rm d}y-1\right)+r}{\lambda}

for a class of traveling fronts connecting r𝑟r and 00 is of some important spreading properties. More precisely, let u​(t,x;u0)𝑢𝑡𝑥subscript𝑢0u(t,x;u_{0}) be the nonnegative solution with compactly supported initial data u0subscript𝑢0u_{0}, then limt→∞,|x|≥c​tu​(t,x;u0)=0subscriptformulae-sequence→𝑡𝑥𝑐𝑡𝑢𝑡𝑥subscript𝑢00\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty,|x|\geq ct}u(t,x;u_{0})=0 for any c>c∗𝑐superscript𝑐c>c^{*} and limt→∞,|x|≤c​tu​(t,x;u0)=rsubscriptformulae-sequence→𝑡𝑥𝑐𝑡𝑢𝑡𝑥subscript𝑢0𝑟\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty,|x|\leq ct}u(t,x;u_{0})=r for any 0<c<c∗0𝑐superscript𝑐0<c<c^{*}. Ecologically, the spreading speed can be understood as the asymptotic rate at which a species, initially introduced in a bounded domain, expands its spatial range as time evolves, while a traveling wave describes the propagation of a species as a wave with a fixed shape and a fixed speed. These two fundamental issues along with some new types of entire solutions have been widely used for the description of species invasion and disease transmission. Regarding the nonlocal dispersal equation with time and/or space periodic dependence, we refer the readers to [29, 31, 25] for spreading speeds, and [30, 7, 25, 1] for traveling wave solutions, and [18] for new types of entire solutions.

When equation (1.1) is used to model the population dynamics of a species, it is assumed that the underlying environment is not patchy and the internal interaction of the organisms is nonlocal. Conversely, if we assume that the organisms move randomly between the adjacent spatial locations, then it is more effective to use the following classical reaction-diffusion equation

ut​(t,x)=d​Δ​u​(t,x)+u​(t,x)​(r​(x−c​t)−u​(t,x)),t>0,x∈ℝ,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑢𝑡𝑡𝑥𝑑Δ𝑢𝑡𝑥𝑢𝑡𝑥𝑟𝑥𝑐𝑡𝑢𝑡𝑥formulae-sequence𝑡0𝑥ℝu_{t}(t,x)=d\Delta u(t,x)+u(t,x)(r(x-ct)-u(t,x)),~{}t>0,x\in\mathbb{R}, (1.2)

and if the species live in patchy environments, the lattice differential equation of the form

ut​(t,x)=d​[u​(t,x+1)−2​u​(t,x)+u​(t,x−1)]+u​(t,x)​(r​(x−c​t)−u​(t,x)),t>0,x∈ℤ,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑢𝑡𝑡𝑥𝑑delimited-[]𝑢𝑡𝑥12𝑢𝑡𝑥𝑢𝑡𝑥1𝑢𝑡𝑥𝑟𝑥𝑐𝑡𝑢𝑡𝑥formulae-sequence𝑡0𝑥ℤu_{t}(t,x)=d[u(t,x+1)-2u(t,x)+u(t,x-1)]+u(t,x)(r(x-ct)-u(t,x)),~{}t>0,x\in\mathbb{Z}, (1.3)

is more meaningful. Note that equations (1.1)-(1.3) are neither homogeneous nor periodic, but possess special heterogeneity with the form of “spatial shifting” at a constant speed. Therefore, we cannot directly apply the abstract theory developed for monotone semiflows in [19, 20, 9] to address the issue of spreading speeds and traveling wave solutions. Certain ad hoc techniques that fit the equation itself are needed and necessary. Recently, Li and his collaborators [15, 11] studied the spatial dynamics of (1.3) and (1.2), respectively, and they showed that the long term behavior of solutions depends on the speed of the shifting habitat edge c𝑐c and a number c∗​(∞)superscript𝑐c^{*}(\infty), where c∗​(∞)=2​d​r​(∞)superscript𝑐2𝑑𝑟c^{*}(\infty)=2\sqrt{dr(\infty)} for (1.2) and c∗​(∞)=infλ>04​d​sinh2⁡(λ/2)+r​(∞)λsuperscript𝑐subscriptinfimum𝜆04𝑑superscript2𝜆2𝑟𝜆c^{*}(\infty)=\inf_{\lambda>0}\frac{4d\sinh^{2}(\lambda/2)+r(\infty)}{\lambda} for (1.3). More accurately, they demonstrated that if c>c∗​(∞)𝑐superscript𝑐c>c^{*}(\infty), then the species will become extinct in the habitat, and if 0<c<c∗​(∞)0𝑐superscript𝑐0<c<c^{*}(\infty), then the species will persist and spread along the shifting habitat at the asymptotic spreading speed c∗​(∞)superscript𝑐c^{*}(\infty). Very recently, by the monotone iterative method, Hu and Zou [12] proved that (1.2) admits a monotone traveling wave solution connecting 00 to r​(∞)𝑟r(\infty) with the speed being the habitat shifting speed, which indeed accounts for an extinction wave. Here we remark that by a change of variable v​(t,x)=u​(t,−x)𝑣𝑡𝑥𝑢𝑡𝑥v(t,x)=u(t,-x), such a forced traveling wave for (1.2) can also be obtained from [8, Theorem 2.1(i)], as applied to the resulting equation. In addition, Li et al. [16] considered this type of problem using an integro-difference equation model in an expanding or contracting habitat. In this paper, we propose to extend the above existing results on equations (1.2) and (1.3) to our nonlocal dispersal problem (1.1). To summarize, we first study the persistence and spreading speed properties by applying the comparison principle and constructing an appropriate subsolution, and then establish the existence of traveling wave solutions by constructing super/sub-solution and using the method of monotone iteration. We should point out that the combination of nonlocal effects and shifting environment makes the analysis on model (1.1) more difficult. In particular, the construction of some appropriate subsolutions to study the spreading speed and traveling waves are highly nontrivial.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we give some preliminaries including the uniqueness and existence of solutions and the comparison principle. Section 3 is devoted to the persistence and spreading speed. Finally, we study the traveling wave solutions in Section 4.

On the other hand, by (2.4), the solution of (2.1) with initial value ψ​(x)=C𝜓𝑥𝐶\psi(x)=C can be expressed by C=∫ℝG​(t,y)​C​dy𝐶subscriptℝ𝐺𝑡𝑦𝐶differential-d𝑦C=\int_{\mathbb{R}}G(t,y)C{\rm d}y, which indicates that ∫ℝG​(t,y)​dy=1subscriptℝ𝐺𝑡𝑦differential-d𝑦1\int_{\mathbb{R}}G(t,y){\rm d}y=1 for all t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0. Let f​(x,u)=u​(r​(x)−u)𝑓𝑥𝑢𝑢𝑟𝑥𝑢f(x,u)=u(r(x)-u). For any 0≤u1,u2≤r​(∞)formulae-sequence0subscript𝑢1subscript𝑢2𝑟0\leq u_{1},u_{2}\leq r(\infty) and −∞<x<∞𝑥-\infty<x<\infty, we can easily verify that

|f​(x,u1)−f​(x,u2)|≤(max⁡{−r​(−∞),r​(∞)}+2​r​(∞))​|u1−u2|,𝑓𝑥subscript𝑢1𝑓𝑥subscript𝑢2𝑟𝑟2𝑟subscript𝑢1subscript𝑢2|f(x,u_{1})-f(x,u_{2})|\leq(\max\{-r(-\infty),r(\infty)\}+2r(\infty))|u_{1}-u_{2}|,

which indicates that f​(x,u)𝑓𝑥𝑢f(x,u) is Lipschitz continuous in u∈[0,r​(∞)]𝑢0𝑟u\in[0,r(\infty)]. Choose ρ>2​r​(∞)−r​(−∞)𝜌2𝑟𝑟\rho>2r(\infty)-r(-\infty), then ρ​u+f​(x,u)𝜌𝑢𝑓𝑥𝑢\rho u+f(x,u) is nondecreasing in u∈[0,r​(∞)]𝑢0𝑟u\in[0,r(\infty)]. Consider the equivalent equation obtained by adding the linear term ρ​u​(t,x)𝜌𝑢𝑡𝑥\rho u(t,x) to both sides of (1.1):

∂u​(t,x)∂t+ρ​u​(t,x)=d​(J∗u−u)​(t,x)+u​(t,x)​(ρ+r​(x−c​t)−u​(t,x)).𝑢𝑡𝑥𝑡𝜌𝑢𝑡𝑥𝑑∗𝐽𝑢𝑢𝑡𝑥𝑢𝑡𝑥𝜌𝑟𝑥𝑐𝑡𝑢𝑡𝑥\frac{\partial u(t,x)}{\partial t}+\rho u(t,x)=d\left(J\ast u-u\right)(t,x)+u(t,x)(\rho+r(x-ct)-u(t,x)). (2.5)

Set 𝕐r​(∞):={ψ∈𝕐:0≤ψ​(x)≤r​(∞),∀x∈ℝ}assignsubscript𝕐𝑟conditional-set𝜓𝕐formulae-sequence0𝜓𝑥𝑟for-all𝑥ℝ\mathbb{Y}_{r(\infty)}:=\{\psi\in\mathbb{Y}:0\leq\psi(x)\leq r(\infty),\forall x\in\mathbb{R}\}. The mild solution of equation (2.5) or (1.1) with u​(0,⋅)=u0​(⋅)∈𝕐r​(∞)𝑢0⋅subscript𝑢0⋅subscript𝕐𝑟u(0,\cdot)=u_{0}(\cdot)\in\mathbb{Y}_{r(\infty)} can be expressed as a fixed point of the nonlinear integral equation in C​(ℝ+,𝕐r​(∞))𝐶subscriptℝsubscript𝕐𝑟C(\mathbb{R}_{+},\mathbb{Y}_{r(\infty)}):

u​(t,x)=[𝒩​u]​(t,x)≜[e−ρ​t​P​(t)​u0]​(x)+∫0te−ρ​(t−s)​P​(t−s)​u​(s,x)​(ρ+r​(x−c​s)−u​(s,x))​ds.𝑢𝑡𝑥delimited-[]𝒩𝑢𝑡𝑥≜delimited-[]superscript𝑒𝜌𝑡𝑃𝑡subscript𝑢0𝑥superscriptsubscript0𝑡superscript𝑒𝜌𝑡𝑠𝑃𝑡𝑠𝑢𝑠𝑥𝜌𝑟𝑥𝑐𝑠𝑢𝑠𝑥differential-d𝑠\begin{split}u(t,x)=&[\mathcal{N}u](t,x)\\ \triangleq&[e^{-\rho t}P(t)u_{0}](x)+\int_{0}^{t}e^{-\rho(t-s)}P(t-s)u(s,x)(\rho+r(x-cs)-u(s,x)){\rm d}s.\end{split} (2.6)

With the expression of P​(t)𝑃𝑡P(t), a direct calculation shows that

∂[P​(t)​ψ]​(x)∂t=−d​[P​(t)​ψ]​(x)+d​∫ℝJ​(y)​[P​(t)​ψ]​(x−y)​dy,delimited-[]𝑃𝑡𝜓𝑥𝑡𝑑delimited-[]𝑃𝑡𝜓𝑥𝑑subscriptℝ𝐽𝑦delimited-[]𝑃𝑡𝜓𝑥𝑦differential-d𝑦\frac{\partial[P(t)\psi](x)}{\partial t}=-d[P(t)\psi](x)+d\int_{\mathbb{R}}J(y)[P(t)\psi](x-y){\rm d}y,

which indicates that the right-side of (2.6) is differential with respect to t𝑡t. Thus, u​(t,x)𝑢𝑡𝑥u(t,x) is a classical solution of equation (2.5) or (1.1).

Definition 2.2.

u∈C​([0,T),𝕐+)𝑢𝐶0𝑇subscript𝕐u\in C([0,T),\mathbb{Y}_{+}) with 0<T≤∞0𝑇0<T\leq\infty is called a supersolution (subsolution) of (2.6) if u​(t,x)≥(≤)​[𝒩​u]​(t,x)𝑢𝑡𝑥delimited-[]𝒩𝑢𝑡𝑥u(t,x)\geq(\leq)[\mathcal{N}u](t,x) for all t∈[0,T)𝑡0𝑇t\in[0,T) and x∈ℝ𝑥ℝx\in\mathbb{R}.

Remark 2.1.

If u∈C​([0,T),𝕐+)𝑢𝐶0𝑇subscript𝕐u\in C([0,T),\mathbb{Y}_{+}) being C1superscript𝐶1C^{1} in t∈(0,T)𝑡0𝑇t\in(0,T) satisfies (2.5) or (1.1) with `​`="``"``=" being replaced by `​`≥"``"``\geq" (`​`≤"``"``\leq") and u​(0,x)≥(≤)​u0​(x)𝑢0𝑥subscript𝑢0𝑥u(0,x)\geq(\leq)u_{0}(x), then it follows from the positivity of P​(t)𝑃𝑡P(t) that u𝑢u is a supersolution (subsolution) of (2.6). Moreover, we can easily verify that u≡r​(∞)𝑢𝑟u\equiv r(\infty) and u≡0𝑢0u\equiv 0 are a supersolution and a trivial subsolution of (2.6), respectively.

Now we consider the sequence {un​(t,x)}superscript𝑢𝑛𝑡𝑥\{u^{n}(t,x)\} generated by

Theorem 2.3.

Let u0∈𝕐r​(∞)subscript𝑢0subscript𝕐𝑟u_{0}\in\mathbb{Y}_{r(\infty)}. Then equation (2.6) admits a unique solution u∈C​(ℝ+,𝕐r​(∞))𝑢𝐶subscriptℝsubscript𝕐𝑟u\in C(\mathbb{R}_{+},\mathbb{Y}_{r(\infty)}). Moreover, the comparison principle holds for (2.6), i.e., if u1​(t,x)subscript𝑢1𝑡𝑥u_{1}(t,x) and u2​(t,x)subscript𝑢2𝑡𝑥u_{2}(t,x) are two solutions of (2.6) associated with initial value u10,u20∈𝕐r​(∞)subscript𝑢10subscript𝑢20subscript𝕐𝑟u_{10},u_{20}\in\mathbb{Y}_{r(\infty)}, respectively, with u10​(x)≤u20​(x)subscript𝑢10𝑥subscript𝑢20𝑥u_{10}(x)\leq u_{20}(x) for all x∈ℝ𝑥ℝx\in\mathbb{R}, then u1​(t,x)≤u2​(t,x)subscript𝑢1𝑡𝑥subscript𝑢2𝑡𝑥u_{1}(t,x)\leq u_{2}(t,x) for all t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0 and x∈ℝ𝑥ℝx\in\mathbb{R}. If we further assume that u10≢u20not-equivalent-tosubscript𝑢10subscript𝑢20u_{10}\not\equiv u_{20}, then u1​(t,x)<u2​(t,x)subscript𝑢1𝑡𝑥subscript𝑢2𝑡𝑥u_{1}(t,x)<u_{2}(t,x) for all t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0 and x∈ℝ𝑥ℝx\in\mathbb{R}.

Proof.

This proof is based a classical super-sub solution method and we only give a sketch here. Define u¯n+1​(t,x)=[𝒩​u¯n]​(t,x)superscript¯𝑢𝑛1𝑡𝑥delimited-[]𝒩superscript¯𝑢𝑛𝑡𝑥\underline{u}^{n+1}(t,x)=[\mathcal{N}\underline{u}^{n}](t,x) with u¯0​(t,x)=0superscript¯𝑢0𝑡𝑥0\underline{u}^{0}(t,x)=0, and u¯n+1​(t,x)=[𝒩​u¯n]​(t,x)superscript¯𝑢𝑛1𝑡𝑥delimited-[]𝒩superscript¯𝑢𝑛𝑡𝑥\bar{u}^{n+1}(t,x)=[\mathcal{N}\bar{u}^{n}](t,x) with u¯0​(t,x)=r​(∞)superscript¯𝑢0𝑡𝑥𝑟\bar{u}^{0}(t,x)=r(\infty). which implies that the pointwise limits

u¯​(t,x):=limn→∞u¯n​(t,x)​ and ​u¯​(t,x):=limn→∞u¯n​(t,x)assign¯𝑢𝑡𝑥subscript→𝑛superscript¯𝑢𝑛𝑡𝑥 and ¯𝑢𝑡𝑥assignsubscript→𝑛superscript¯𝑢𝑛𝑡𝑥\underline{u}(t,x):=\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\underline{u}^{n}(t,x)\text{ and }\bar{u}(t,x):=\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\bar{u}^{n}(t,x)

both exist and satisfy that 0≤u¯≤u¯≤r​(∞)0¯𝑢¯𝑢𝑟0\leq\underline{u}\leq\bar{u}\leq r(\infty). Moreover, both u¯¯𝑢\underline{u} and u¯¯𝑢\bar{u} are solutions of (2.6) in C​(ℝ+,𝕐r​(∞))𝐶subscriptℝsubscript𝕐𝑟C(\mathbb{R}_{+},\mathbb{Y}_{r(\infty)}). We now prove u¯​(t,x)=u¯​(t,x)¯𝑢𝑡𝑥¯𝑢𝑡𝑥\underline{u}(t,x)=\bar{u}(t,x). Note that for any ψ∈𝕐𝜓𝕐\psi\in\mathbb{Y}, ‖a0​(ψ)‖=‖ψ‖normsubscript𝑎0𝜓norm𝜓\|a_{0}(\psi)\|=\|\psi\|, ∥a1(ψ)∥=∥∫ℝJ(y)a0(ψ)(⋅−y)dy∥≤∥ψ∥\|a_{1}(\psi)\|=\|\int_{\mathbb{R}}J(y)a_{0}(\psi)(\cdot-y){\rm d}y\|\leq\|\psi\|, by induction, we can claim that ‖ak​(ψ)‖≤‖ψ‖normsubscript𝑎𝑘𝜓norm𝜓\|a_{k}(\psi)\|\leq\|\psi\| for all k=0,1,2,⋯𝑘012⋯k=0,1,2,\cdot\cdot\cdot. By using (2.2), we obtain

‖P​(t)​ψ‖≤e−d​t​∑k=0∞(d​t)kk!​‖ak​(ψ)‖≤‖ψ‖​ for all ​t≥0.norm𝑃𝑡𝜓superscript𝑒𝑑𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘0superscript𝑑𝑡𝑘𝑘normsubscript𝑎𝑘𝜓norm𝜓 for all 𝑡0\|P(t)\psi\|\leq e^{-dt}\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{(dt)^{k}}{k!}\|a_{k}(\psi)\|\leq\|\psi\|\text{ for all }t\geq 0. (2.8)

Therefore, by (2.6) and (2.8), a direct calculation yields that

which shows that

Then the Gronwall’s inequality implies that 0≤eρ​t​‖u¯​(t,⋅)−u¯​(t,⋅)‖≤00superscript𝑒𝜌𝑡norm¯𝑢𝑡⋅¯𝑢𝑡⋅00\leq e^{\rho t}\|\bar{u}(t,\cdot)-\underline{u}(t,\cdot)\|\leq 0. This implies that u¯​(t,x)=u¯​(t,x)¯𝑢𝑡𝑥¯𝑢𝑡𝑥\underline{u}(t,x)=\bar{u}(t,x) for all t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0 and x∈ℝ𝑥ℝx\in\mathbb{R}. The comparison principle is a straightforward consequence of the construction for solutions. Using the strongly positivity of P​(t)𝑃𝑡P(t), we can easily prove the last conclusion of this theorem. ∎

The following result is a simple consequence of Theorem 2.3.

Corollary 2.4.

Let u,v∈C​(ℝ+,𝕐r​(∞))𝑢𝑣𝐶subscriptℝsubscript𝕐𝑟u,v\in C(\mathbb{R}_{+},\mathbb{Y}_{r(\infty)}) be the supersolution and subsolution of (2.6) for all (t,x)∈ℝ+×ℝ𝑡𝑥subscriptℝℝ(t,x)\in\mathbb{R}_{+}\times\mathbb{R}, respectively. If u​(0,x)≥v​(0,x)𝑢0𝑥𝑣0𝑥u(0,x)\geq v(0,x) for all x∈ℝ𝑥ℝx\in\mathbb{R}, then u​(t,x)≥v​(t,x)𝑢𝑡𝑥𝑣𝑡𝑥u(t,x)\geq v(t,x) for all (t,x)∈ℝ+×ℝ𝑡𝑥subscriptℝℝ(t,x)\in\mathbb{R}_{+}\times\mathbb{R}.

Proof.

According to the positivity of P​(t)𝑃𝑡P(t) and the choice of ρ𝜌\rho (i.e., ρ>2​r​(∞)−r​(−∞)𝜌2𝑟𝑟\rho>2r(\infty)-r(-\infty)), which guarantees the monotonicity of ρ​u+f​(x−c​t,u)𝜌𝑢𝑓𝑥𝑐𝑡𝑢\rho u+f(x-ct,u)), we can claim that the nonlinear operator 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} defined by (2.6) is order preserving in the sense that

u(t,x)≥[𝒩u](t,x)≥[𝒩ku](t,x)≥⋯≥limk→∞[𝒩ku](t,x)=:u~(t,x)\displaystyle u(t,x)\geq[\mathcal{N}u](t,x)\geq[\mathcal{N}^{k}u](t,x)\geq\cdot\cdot\cdot\geq\lim_{k\rightarrow\infty}[\mathcal{N}^{k}u](t,x)=:\tilde{u}(t,x)
 and v(t,x)≤[𝒩v](t,x)≤[𝒩kv](t,x)≤⋯≤limk→∞[𝒩kv](t,x)=:v~(t,x).\displaystyle\text{ and }v(t,x)\leq[\mathcal{N}v](t,x)\leq[\mathcal{N}^{k}v](t,x)\leq\cdot\cdot\cdot\leq\lim_{k\rightarrow\infty}[\mathcal{N}^{k}v](t,x)=:\tilde{v}(t,x).

Clearly, u~​(0,x)=u​(0,x)~𝑢0𝑥𝑢0𝑥\tilde{u}(0,x)=u(0,x) and v~​(0,x)=v​(0,x)~𝑣0𝑥𝑣0𝑥\tilde{v}(0,x)=v(0,x). Moreover, both u~​(t,x)~𝑢𝑡𝑥\tilde{u}(t,x) and v~​(t,x)~𝑣𝑡𝑥\tilde{v}(t,x) are the solutions of (2.6), and hence, Theorem 2.3 implies that u​(t,x)≥u~​(t,x)≥v~​(t,x)≥v​(t,x)𝑢𝑡𝑥~𝑢𝑡𝑥~𝑣𝑡𝑥𝑣𝑡𝑥u(t,x)\geq\tilde{u}(t,x)\geq\tilde{v}(t,x)\geq v(t,x) because u~​(0,x)≥v~​(0,x)~𝑢0𝑥~𝑣0𝑥\tilde{u}(0,x)\geq\tilde{v}(0,x), which derive the requested result. ∎

3 Persistence and spreading speeds

In this section, we first show that the species will become extinct in the long run if the edge of the habitat shifts relatively fast. For r​(x)>0𝑟𝑥0r(x)>0 and λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0, we define

ϕ​(x;λ)=d​(∫ℝJ​(y)​eλ​y​dy−1)+r​(x)λ.italic-ϕ𝑥𝜆𝑑subscriptℝ𝐽𝑦superscript𝑒𝜆𝑦differential-d𝑦1𝑟𝑥𝜆\phi(x;\lambda)=\frac{d\left(\int_{\mathbb{R}}J(y)e^{\lambda y}{\rm d}y-1\right)+r(x)}{\lambda}.

Clearly, ϕ​(x;λ)>0italic-ϕ𝑥𝜆0\phi(x;\lambda)>0 and ϕ​(x;λ)→∞→italic-ϕ𝑥𝜆\phi(x;\lambda)\rightarrow\infty as λ→0→𝜆0\lambda\rightarrow 0. On the other hand,

ϕ​(x;λ)=d​(∫ℝJ​(y)​Σn=0∞​(λ​y)nn!​dy−1)+r​(x)λ=d​∫ℝJ​(y)​Σm=1∞​(λ​y)2​m(2​m)!​dy+r​(x)λ=d​Σm=1∞​λ2​m−1​∫ℝJ​(y)​y2​m​dy(2​m)!+r​(x)λ→∞​ as ​λ→∞italic-ϕ𝑥𝜆𝑑subscriptℝ𝐽𝑦superscriptsubscriptΣ𝑛0superscript𝜆𝑦𝑛𝑛differential-d𝑦1𝑟𝑥𝜆𝑑subscriptℝ𝐽𝑦superscriptsubscriptΣ𝑚1superscript𝜆𝑦2𝑚2𝑚differential-d𝑦𝑟𝑥𝜆𝑑superscriptsubscriptΣ𝑚1superscript𝜆2𝑚1subscriptℝ𝐽𝑦superscript𝑦2𝑚differential-d𝑦2𝑚𝑟𝑥𝜆→ as 𝜆→\begin{split}\phi(x;\lambda)=&\frac{d\left(\int_{\mathbb{R}}J(y)\Sigma_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{(\lambda y)^{n}}{n!}{\rm d}y-1\right)+r(x)}{\lambda}\\ =&\frac{d\int_{\mathbb{R}}J(y)\Sigma_{m=1}^{\infty}\frac{(\lambda y)^{2m}}{(2m)!}{\rm d}y+r(x)}{\lambda}\\ =&d\Sigma_{m=1}^{\infty}\frac{\lambda^{2m-1}\int_{\mathbb{R}}J(y)y^{2m}{\rm d}y}{(2m)!}+\frac{r(x)}{\lambda}\rightarrow\infty\text{ as }\lambda\rightarrow\infty\end{split}

and

In the rest of this section, we consider the case that the edge of habitat is moving at a speed less than c∗​(∞)superscript𝑐c^{*}(\infty). The construction of a suitable subsolution plays a key role in our theoretical analysis. To proceed, we introduce an auxiliary function that can be found in Weinberger’s pioneering work [32], see also [15, 11]. For λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0 and γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0, define

υ​(x;λ,γ)={e−λ​x​sin⁡(γ​x),if ​0≤x≤π/γ,0,elsewhere.𝜐𝑥𝜆𝛾casessuperscript𝑒𝜆𝑥𝛾𝑥if 0𝑥𝜋𝛾0elsewhere\upsilon(x;\lambda,\gamma)=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}e^{-\lambda x}\sin(\gamma x),&\text{if }0\leq x\leq\pi/\gamma,\\ 0,&\text{elsewhere}.\end{array}\right.

Note that υ​(x;λ,γ)𝜐𝑥𝜆𝛾\upsilon(x;\lambda,\gamma) is nonnegative, continuous in x∈ℝ𝑥ℝx\in\mathbb{R} and continuously differentiable when x≠0,π/γ𝑥0𝜋𝛾x\neq 0,\pi/\gamma. Moreover, υ​(x;λ,γ)𝜐𝑥𝜆𝛾\upsilon(x;\lambda,\gamma) takes the maximum at the point x=σ​(λ,γ):=(1/γ)​arctan⁡(γ/λ)∈(0,π/γ)𝑥𝜎𝜆𝛾assign1𝛾𝛾𝜆0𝜋𝛾x=\sigma(\lambda,\gamma):=(1/\gamma)\arctan(\gamma/\lambda)\in(0,\pi/\gamma). Note that σ​(λ,γ)𝜎𝜆𝛾\sigma(\lambda,\gamma) is strictly decreasing in λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0 and also that the maximum υ​(σ​(λ,γ);λ,γ)∈(0,1)𝜐𝜎𝜆𝛾𝜆𝛾01\upsilon(\sigma(\lambda,\gamma);\lambda,\gamma)\in(0,1).

Define

Assume that the compact support of the kernel J𝐽J is [−L,L]𝐿𝐿[-L,L]. Since J𝐽J is symmetric, we have

which indicates that φ​(λ,γ)𝜑𝜆𝛾\varphi(\lambda,\gamma) is increasing in λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0. Let

Since the parameters δ𝛿\delta, ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, ι𝜄\iota can be chosen arbitrarily small, we then obtain

On the other hand, Theorem 2.3 implies that 0≤u​(t,x)≤r​(∞)0𝑢𝑡𝑥𝑟0\leq u(t,x)\leq r(\infty) for all t>0𝑡0t>0 and x∈ℝ𝑥ℝx\in\mathbb{R}. In particular, we have

limt→∞sup(c+ς)​t≤x≤(c∗​(∞)−ς)​tu​(t,x)≤r​(∞),subscript→𝑡subscriptsupremum𝑐𝜍𝑡𝑥superscript𝑐𝜍𝑡𝑢𝑡𝑥𝑟\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}\sup_{(c+\varsigma)t\leq x\leq(c^{*}(\infty)-\varsigma)t}u(t,x)\leq r(\infty),

which implies that the statement (iii) is valid. ∎

We remark that the persistence obtained in Theorem 3.3 should be understood from the view of “by moving”, that is, the species will move toward the better resource with speed c∗​(∞)superscript𝑐c^{*}(\infty) which is larger than the shifting speed c𝑐c. In fact, for any given location x𝑥x, since the resource function r​(x−c​t)𝑟𝑥𝑐𝑡r(x-ct) will become negative eventually as time goes, then the population at this location will vanish.

4 Forced traveling waves

In this section, we consider the positive traveling wave solutions of (1.1) with the wave speed at which the habitat is shifting.

Letting u​(t,x)=U​(ξ)𝑢𝑡𝑥𝑈𝜉u(t,x)=U(\xi) with ξ=x−c​t𝜉𝑥𝑐𝑡\xi=x-ct, we see from (1.1) that U​(ξ)𝑈𝜉U(\xi) satisfies

−c​U′​(ξ)=d​(∫ℝJ​(y)​U​(ξ−y)​dy−U​(ξ))+U​(ξ)​(r​(ξ)−U​(ξ)),ξ∈ℝ,formulae-sequence𝑐superscript𝑈′𝜉𝑑subscriptℝ𝐽𝑦𝑈𝜉𝑦differential-d𝑦𝑈𝜉𝑈𝜉𝑟𝜉𝑈𝜉𝜉ℝ-cU^{\prime}(\xi)=d\left(\int_{\mathbb{R}}J(y)U(\xi-y){\rm d}y-U(\xi)\right)+U(\xi)(r(\xi)-U(\xi)),~{}\xi\in\mathbb{R}, (4.1)

where the symbol prime stands for the derivative. Recall that c>0𝑐0c>0 is the habitat shifting speed. As explained in [12], we impose the following boundary conditions

limξ→−∞U​(ξ)=0,limξ→∞U​(ξ)=r​(∞).formulae-sequencesubscript→𝜉𝑈𝜉0subscript→𝜉𝑈𝜉𝑟\lim_{\xi\rightarrow-\infty}U(\xi)=0,~{}\lim_{\xi\rightarrow\infty}U(\xi)=r(\infty). (4.2)

This type of traveling waves can help us understand the point-wise “die-out dynamics” of the species under consideration . By Remark 2.1, we have 0≤U​(ξ)≤r​(∞)0𝑈𝜉𝑟0\leq U(\xi)\leq r(\infty), ∀ξ∈ℝfor-all𝜉ℝ\forall\xi\in\mathbb{R}. Moreover, by the strong maximum principles for nonlocal equations [5, Theorem 2.12], we get 0<U<r​(∞)0𝑈𝑟0<U<r(\infty) in ℝℝ\mathbb{R}.

Let V​(ξ)=U​(−ξ)𝑉𝜉𝑈𝜉V(\xi)=U(-\xi), ∀ξ∈ℝfor-all𝜉ℝ\forall\xi\in\mathbb{R}. It then follows from (4.1) and the symmetry of J𝐽J that

c​V′​(ξ)=d​(∫ℝJ​(y)​V​(ξ−y)​dy−V​(ξ))+V​(ξ)​(r​(−ξ)−V​(ξ)),ξ∈ℝ.formulae-sequence𝑐superscript𝑉′𝜉𝑑subscriptℝ𝐽𝑦𝑉𝜉𝑦differential-d𝑦𝑉𝜉𝑉𝜉𝑟𝜉𝑉𝜉𝜉ℝcV^{\prime}(\xi)=d\left(\int_{\mathbb{R}}J(y)V(\xi-y){\rm d}y-V(\xi)\right)+V(\xi)(r(-\xi)-V(\xi)),~{}\xi\in\mathbb{R}. (4.3)

Correspondingly, we have

limξ→−∞V​(ξ)=r​(∞),limξ→∞V​(ξ)=0.formulae-sequencesubscript→𝜉𝑉𝜉𝑟subscript→𝜉𝑉𝜉0\lim_{\xi\rightarrow-\infty}V(\xi)=r(\infty),~{}\lim_{\xi\rightarrow\infty}V(\xi)=0. (4.4)

In the following, by the combination of super/sub-solutions and monotone iterations, we will prove that (4.3) admits a nonincreasing solution satisfying (4.4) for any given c>0𝑐0c>0, which gives rise to the nondecreasing traveling wave solution of (1.1) connecting 00 to r​(∞)𝑟r(\infty).

In order to construct a subsolution for (4.3), we introduce an auxiliary nonlocal dispersal equation of ignition type. For any small ε∈(0,r​(∞)/5)𝜀0𝑟5\varepsilon\in(0,r(\infty)/5), define

∂u​(t,x)∂t=d​(J∗u−u)​(t,x)+fε​(u​(t,x)).𝑢𝑡𝑥𝑡𝑑∗𝐽𝑢𝑢𝑡𝑥subscript𝑓𝜀𝑢𝑡𝑥\frac{\partial u(t,x)}{\partial t}=d(J\ast u-u)(t,x)+f_{\varepsilon}(u(t,x)). (4.5)

Next, we construct a supersolution for equation (4.3).

Lemma 4.3.

Now we are in a position to prove our main result in this section.

Theorem 4.5.

For any given c>0𝑐0c>0, (4.1) admits a nondecreasing positive solution U​(ξ)𝑈𝜉U(\xi) satisfying (4.2). In other words, (1.1) has a nondecreasing forced traveling wave connecting 00 and r​(∞)𝑟r(\infty) with the wave speed at which the environment is shifting. If, in addition, r𝑟r is strictly increasing, then the wave profile is monotone increasing.

Proof.

V¯​(ξ)≤Vn+1​(ξ)≤Vn​(ξ)≤V¯​(ξ),∀ξ∈ℝ,n≥1.formulae-sequence¯𝑉𝜉subscript𝑉𝑛1𝜉subscript𝑉𝑛𝜉¯𝑉𝜉formulae-sequencefor-all𝜉ℝ𝑛1\underline{V}(\xi)\leq V_{n+1}(\xi)\leq V_{n}(\xi)\leq\overline{V}(\xi),~{}\forall\xi\in\mathbb{R},n\geq 1.

Then the pointwise limit of the sequence {Vn}subscript𝑉𝑛\{V_{n}\} exists, denoted by V𝑉V, i.e., for every ξ∈ℝ𝜉ℝ\xi\in\mathbb{R}, V​(ξ)=limn→∞Vn​(ξ)𝑉𝜉subscript→𝑛subscript𝑉𝑛𝜉V(\xi)=\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}V_{n}(\xi). Obviously, V​(ξ)𝑉𝜉V(\xi) is a nonincreasing and nonnegative function defined on ℝℝ\mathbb{R} and

V¯​(ξ)≤V​(ξ)≤V¯​(ξ).¯𝑉𝜉𝑉𝜉¯𝑉𝜉\underline{V}(\xi)\leq V(\xi)\leq\overline{V}(\xi). (4.17)

Moreover, H​(Vn)𝐻subscript𝑉𝑛H(V_{n}) converges pointwise to H​(V)𝐻𝑉H(V).

by (4.13) and the Lebesgue’s dominated convergence theorem, we have
